name: 3,3,3-trifluoro-2-hydroxy-2-(trifluoromethyl)propionic acid
Reason: 3,3,3-trifluoro-2-hydroxy-2-(trifluoromethyl)propionic acid has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of three fluorine atoms, which significantly increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the rigidity of the structure. Fluorine substituents tend to enhance the melting point by approximately +10°C due to the increased molecular weight and the rigidity of the structure. Additionally, the trifluoromethyl group introduces a hydrogen bonding potential, which can contribute to the melting point. The hydrogen bonding potential can be estimated at approximately +5°C.
